Yes, it is common sense that happy and healthy employees lead to better productivity and higher profits in the long run. However, some businesses still prioritize profits over the wellbeing of their workers.

This is often due to a short-term focus on quarterly profits and a lack of understanding of the long-term benefits of investing in employee wellbeing. Some business leaders may see employee wellbeing as an expense rather than an investment, and they may not believe that it directly correlates with business success.

It is important for businesses to understand that investing in employee wellbeing is not only ethical but also leads to tangible benefits such as increased productivity, higher employee retention rates, lower healthcare costs, and improved public reputation. A positive work environment can also attract top talent and lead to increased innovation and creativity.

Furthermore, corporate social responsibility has become increasingly important to consumers, with many people choosing to spend their money on companies that prioritize employee wellbeing and social and environmental responsibility.

By prioritizing employee wellbeing, businesses can create a more positive and sustainable work environment while also boosting their bottom line.
